unnormalised: **Telecommunications: Fiber-to-Home Expansion Gains Momentum in India**
normalised: **Telecommunications: Fiber-to-Home Expansion Gains Momentum in India**

unnormalised: New Delhi, India – Leading telecom providers are aggressively expanding their Fiber-to-Home (FTTH) infrastructure across India, aiming to bridge the digital divide and cater to the surging demand for high-speed internet. Reliance Jio and Airtel are reportedly investing heavily in laying down thousands of kilometers of fiber optic cables, particularly in Tier 2 and Tier 3 cities.
normalised: New Delhi, India – Leading telecom providers are aggressively expanding their Fiber-to-Home (F T T H) infrastructure across India, aiming to bridge the digital divide and cater to the surging demand for high-speed internet. Reliance Jio and Airtel are reportedly investing heavily in laying down thousands of kilometers of fiber optic cables, particularly in Tier two and Tier three cities.

unnormalised: This initiative aims to provide reliable broadband connectivity to households and businesses, facilitating remote work, online education, and access to digital services. Dr. Sharma, a senior analyst at the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Delhi, notes that “FTTH is crucial for realizing the Digital India vision.”
normalised: This initiative aims to provide reliable broadband connectivity to households and businesses, facilitating remote work, online education, and access to digital services. Doctor Sharma, a senior analyst at the Indian Institute of Technology (I I T) Delhi, notes that “F T T H is crucial for realizing the Digital India vision.”

unnormalised: Bharat Sanchar Nigam Limited (BSNL) is also revamping its existing infrastructure to offer competitive FTTH plans. Preliminary reports suggest that average data consumption per user in FTTH-enabled homes is significantly higher, reaching up to 200 GB per month. The government plans to incentivize further expansion by streamlining regulatory approvals and offering subsidies in rural areas. Real estate developers are increasingly incorporating FTTH connectivity as a standard amenity in new housing projects, offering speeds up to 1 Gbps. Apartment complexes like "Shanti Niketan" in Mumbai now offer residents dedicated FTTH lines, covering over 500,000 sq ft. Investments in FTTH infrastructure are expected to reach Rs. 25,000 Crore in the next fiscal year.
